comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: Thomas Hinton Edward Gallwey lived at Rockfield, Tramore, County Waterford. www.thepeerage.com/p39134.htm He married Nora Mary Kenny, daughter of Patrick Kenny, on 30 October 1928. Rockfield House is miles from Tramore maps.osi.ie/publicviewer/#V1,615866,596430,7,9 It might be nowt to do with this photo...

comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] The bicycle is a Humber, with the little men walking around the chainwheel, which would have probably been nickel-plated at that time? The one below, from 1923, appears to have a black-painted chainwheel/handlebars/etc.!?

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] But it might well be owt to do with this photo, and a great clue to the location that some kind Waterford person might be able to confirm for us! (Is owt the opposite of nowt?) I searched in our catalogue for Rockfield, and this copy of a soldier from October 1943 popped up, ordered by T.H.E. Gallwey.

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: Thomas Hinton Edward Gallwey was born on 28 July 1896. www.thepeerage.com/p39134.htm He was the son of William Joseph Gallwey and Frances Kate Trelawner Davies. 1901 census 1911 census So there was a house called Rockfield on Church Road in Tramore. It is not marked on the OSI map, but it could be this big house. maps.osi.ie/publicviewer/#V1,657842,600998,7,9 Local knowledge needed. Google Maps

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] That should be our slogan, because for all the invaluable web-based resources out there - "Local Knowledge Needed"!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: Another good reason for the NLI to scan old telephone books. Here is part of the 1911 telephone directory Mr W GALLWEY (Justice of the Peace) lives at Rockfield, Phone Tramore 8 also Mr WGD GOFF lives at Glenville, Phone Waterford 5 (he was the first garage man) In those days they were manual telephone exchanges run by the National Telephone Company. Post Office telephones were mainly confined to Call Offices inside each Post Office. The Post Office took over the NTC soon after to create a monopoly, except in Hull which is still independent.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] Checked some phone books. We don't have one for 1911. But all of these listings, including the Goffs and the Gallweys still the same in 1914...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: It would be good if the NLI could scan all their phone books and fill in the gaps between 1911 and 1921. Ancestry does not have a 1914 phone book online except for London. It would be even better not to have an Ancestry paywall for census and directories. The 1901/1911 Irish census is free to view.
